channel.title: Reflection and it's limits
channel.description:
I was wondering some things about reflection, because I'm able to read variables out of something I initiated in the same class. Is it possible to read stuff from something that is running, but you haven't initiated? for example running runescape in your browser and then reading a variable from something you have written?
and if that is possible, how would I go about doing so, because I've been stuck at getting the Class, I've tried using Class.forName(name) but I don't know if I need to put in something else in the name then the name of the class

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

like sema and abraham said, attatch api, use the method premain (if you want to hack it before its loaded), or agentmain (if you want to hack it when you attatch your agent)

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

abraham2119:

attach api, or maybe even the invocation api (if you are willing to write native code)

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @darkmax darkmax
item.description:
@darkmax wrote:

Yeah, Tenen is right. The object has been initialized already, but not from my program. example:
You run RS just regular in your browser, and I want to run reflection on that.
If it’s possible I’d like to know how, but it’s not necessary, because I’ve made a loader already and just do it through that

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

semaphore:

I don’t think you understand the question you’re asking. On the one hand you’re asking if it’s possible to read class info from a class that has not yet been loaded.

almighty semaphore, where does he ever say that?

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

I don’t think you understand the question you’re asking. On the one hand you’re asking if it’s possible to read class info from a class that has not yet been loaded. Then you say the thing that tipped you off to it was someone essentially accessing the value of a static field ( Field.get(…) takes as a param the instance upon which to act - null means the field is static )

So to answer your question - no there is no way to do anything with a class with reflection before that class is loaded.

If you want to access class info before it is loaded just use a java-based agent implementing premain.

That approach works for dynamically changing the classes each time the app is run without making permanent changes to the libs. On the flipside - such processing will be expensive and take a while (potentially each run).

For a more permanent fix patching the app libs will lead to a single cost up front but every subsequent invoke of the app will be relatively quick.

There are a few java-based tools that I hacked using the agent method. A few others I just patch the public key/sigcheck. Each of those use the methods I mentioned respectively.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @darkmax darkmax
item.description:
@darkmax wrote:

Yeah, that was a real shock to me, I found out by looking at some Reflection bot and seeing them do playerField.get(null)
but since I know I can do it like that, I just made a loader that loads the client and it’s working atm

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You don’t have to have initialised the object to reflect on it, but you do have to have a reference to it. As stated above, there are many ways to do that.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

attach api, or maybe even the invocation api (if you are willing to write native code)

item.title: Reflection and it's limits
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

You could do that with a java agent.

Or you could write a loader and instantiate the client then reflect on that.

Read full topic
